bibl.title: Letter from Florence M. Read to Henry Rose Carter, March 30, 1922

div1.p: Read sends Carter extracts from two letters by Hanson. In the first letter Hanson discusses a possible yellow fever outbreak in southern Peru. His second letter deals with rumors of a yellow fever outbreak in the mountains.

Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
You will find enclosed paragraphs from
two letters received this week from Doctor Hanson.
In view of your intimate knowledge of conditions in
Peru, I am sending this information to you, to in-
quire if you have any comments or suggestions to
offer in connection with the closing up of the work.

Mr. Rose has written Doctor Hanson that
the extent to which he should investigate conditions
outside the departments which have been infected,
will be left entirely to his judgment, and has told
him that the work is to stop when he says it is
safe to stop.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Florence M. Read Dr. Henry R. Carter
2121 California Street, N.W.
Washington, D.C.

div1.opener: Extracts from Letters from Doctor Henry Hanson
div1.p:
In regard to your letter of January 23 in which you
speak of the extent of the investigations outside of the infected
territory, I am taking a position which is quite different from what
I would take in the case where one only has to consider the control
of an epidemic. I am placing myself in what I judge to be your posi-
tion in regard to the world program for the eradication of yellow
fever. In such a case and with the circumstance that it seems that
for the first time in history we propose to declare the west coast
of South America free from yellow fever, it is of considerable impor-
tance to know all the terrain which is infectable to this disease and
to know whether there is anything suspicious or whether there has been
recently or when. This was the object with which I directed the
recent tour of investigation by Dr. Caballero, Mr. Dunn and Sr.
Olivari.

We have lately been getting some reports to the effect
that there is a sickness which they designate as black vomit in the
extreme southeastern portion of the country, in the Department Madre
de Dios, this is on the other side of the mountains in the Bolivian-
Brazilian region to the east of the Department of Cuzco. Even if this
is true I think there is very small danger of the reinfection of the
coast, on account of the length of time to get across and the very low
temperature in the mountains. The question is what importance it would
have in the program of the Board in the eradication of the fever. If
the means of communication should be very much improved it might be important
-2-
unless one could depend on a spontaneous elimination. It would be
interesting to hear what Dr. Carter has to say; while he was here in
Peru he seemed to be of the opinion that there would be practically no
danger to the coast from the presence of the disease in Brazil or the
Peruvian territory to the east of the Andes.

There is one other section which we may investigate,
namely the Chanchamayo valley. This is in quite easy communication
by Lima by means of the Central Railway and if there should remain
some focus in that section there would be a possibility of the reintro-
duction of the disease on the coast. I think it better that we should
know what the sanitary conditions of the remotely dangerous places are
in so far as yellow fever possibilities are concerned. Certain individ-
uals who have come down this way have spoken of a “black vomit” in
this (the Chanchamayo) region. This is also on the east of the high
range of the Andes, and the danger from that section is very small,
probably nil.

The Departments of Lambayeque and Libertad seem to be
completely free from infection, and I feel no uneasiness from those
sections. I have sent an inspector to go over the conditions in the
Department of Piura and Dr. Caballero will go up for another inspection
soon. On the coast there has been nothing reported of a suspicious nature.

In my letter to Dr. Rose I spoke of the rumors which we
had received about the presence of yellow fever on the other side of
the mountains, but I have since had an opportunity of talking with a
very intelligent man from the eastern part of the Department of Cuzco
and find that there has been no known cases in that section since 1907,
-3-
which puts an entirely different light on the situation. I was
thinking for a while that it might be necessary to make an inves-
tigation in that region but with this added information unless
something new comes in I do not think it will be necessary. The
Chanchamayo territory is more accessible and I may make an investi-
gation there before we close up all work. It is becoming somewhat
of a problem now to keep up a proper line of investigations, because
as I have indicated we do not want to have the disappointment of
making a premature announcement.
